subtitleNullable: Images of two domestic cats taken by Catmon, a catflap monitoring application
descriptionNullable:
# Introduction
Boo and Simba are two cool cats with a twitter account! Can you tell them apart?

Boo and Simba have been tweeting for over 7 years on the [@boosimba twitter account](https://twitter.com/boosimba). Or to be more precise, *Catmon* - a catflap monitoring application - tweets the cat’s image when a cat enters the house through the catflap.

# Aim
The aim of this dataset is to provide a sufficient number of tagged images to allow Boo and Simba to be automatically identified by a machine learning application.

# Dataset Structure
The *catmon_input* folder contains three folders: boo, simba and unknown. These folder names correspond to the 3 candidate image labels. 

The boo folder contains 1000 images of Boo, a fluffy domestic cat. 

The simba folder contains 1000 images of Simba, a wiry domestic cat. 

The unknown folder contains 793 images in which Boo or Simba cannot be identified. These are mostly images that are too dark, though some are ‘ghost’ images in which no cat is present.

Each image is 640 x 480 (w x h) pixels. The size varies but is typically about 200 KB.

The image filename gives the date and time the image was captured by *Catmon*. For example the image *2021-04-29_145458.jpg* was captured on 29th April 2021 at 14:54:58. 

The time of day effects the brightness of the image. *Catmon* is supported by a motion-sensitive light that isn’t always quick enough to illuminate the scene. Many of the night images are therefore too dark to identify a cat. The lighting has recently been upgraded.

# New Data
*Catmon* continues to tweet new cat images every day on the \@boosimba twitter account.

# References
1. You can find out more about Catmon here: [Catmon GitHub repo](https://github.com/terrydolan/catmon).
1. You can see an example classification model in the associated Kaggle notebook here: [Kaggle Catmon Image Classifier Iteration3 mobilenet_v2 (with GPU)](https://www.kaggle.com/code/terrydolan/catmon-image-classifier-iteration3-mobilenet-v2/notebook)
1. You can see an example *Catmon* image classification application here: [Catmon Image Classifier GitHub repo](https://github.com/terrydolan/catmon-img-classifier). The application processes new Catmon tweets on the \@boosimba twitter account and replies with the cat’s name.
title: Catmon Cats Dataset
subtitle: Images of two domestic cats taken by Catmon, a catflap monitoring application
description:
# Introduction

# Dataset Structure
The *catmon_input* folder contains three folders: boo, simba and unknown. These folder names correspond to the 3 candidate image labels. 

The boo folder contains 1000 images of Boo, a fluffy domestic cat. 

The simba folder contains 1000 images of Simba, a wiry domestic cat. 

The unknown folder contains 793 images in which Boo or Simba cannot be identified. These are mostly images that are too dark, though some are ‘ghost’ images in which no cat is present.

Each image is 640 x 480 (w x h) pixels. The size varies but is typically about 200 KB.

The image filename gives the date and time the image was captured by *Catmon*. For example the image *2021-04-29_145458.jpg* was captured on 29th April 2021 at 14:54:58. 

The time of day effects the brightness of the image. *Catmon* is supported by a motion-sensitive light that isn’t always quick enough to illuminate the scene. Many of the night images are therefore too dark to identify a cat. The lighting has recently been upgraded.

# New Data
*Catmon* continues to tweet new cat images every day on the \@boosimba twitter account.

1. You can find out more about Catmon here: [Catmon GitHub repo](https://github.com/terrydolan/catmon).
1. You can see an example classification model in the associated Kaggle notebook here: [Kaggle Catmon Image Classifier Iteration3 mobilenet_v2 (with GPU)](https://www.kaggle.com/code/terrydolan/catmon-image-classifier-iteration3-mobilenet-v2/notebook)
